summary: Email correspondence between a Senior Forensic Examiner and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the processing of electronic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence and Little St. James island. The examiner apologizes for delays and anticipates having load files ready by Thursday COB, while the prosecutor expresses concern about timing and asks about the status of materials from the island.

persons.name: Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The individual is generating load files for electronic evidence seized from Epstein's properties and anticipates completion by Thursday COB.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York
persons.context: The prosecutor follows up on the processing of electronic evidence from Epstein's New York residence and inquires about materials from the island, expressing concern about timing.

connections.description: Correspondence regarding the processing and transfer of electronic evidence in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Email follow-up on evidence processing
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney follows up on phone conversation about processing electronic evidence from Epstein's New York residence and inquires about island materials.

keyFacts: Electronic evidence from Epstein's New York residence search was being processed by CART, involving approximately 5-6 iMacs and 5 laptop computers.
Load files for Relativity were anticipated to be ready by Thursday COB (November 14, 2019).
The FBI had not yet started processing materials seized from Little St. James island.
The Assistant U.S. Attorney expressed concern about timing, noting the New York materials were 'just the tip of the iceberg'.
